title: PTD Today — Media
disclaimer: Informational only — AI-generated summaries; may contain errors. Verify with the original video.

items.title: How AI Empowers Artists. Watch the full episode on our channel now.

ai.summary: Based on the available description, this film accompanies Season 5 of the Webby Award-winning podcast Where the Internet Lives and examines the unseen world of data centers in the context of AI-enabled creativity. It connects themes of AI, data, and artistic practice while highlighting the infrastructure that supports modern creative tools.
bullets: Film ties to Season 5 of the podcast Where the Internet Lives.
Focuses on the unseen infrastructure of data centers.
Explores how AI empowers artists and creative work.
Highlights intersections of AI, data, and creativity.
No transcript provided for the episode.
takeaways: AI-driven creative tools depend on data center capacity—plan for growth in compute, cooling, and power provisioning.
Greater public storytelling about data centers creates opportunities for outreach on grid impacts and local siting decisions.
Align expansions serving AI workloads with renewable energy and storage strategies to manage load profile and sustainability goals.
Anticipate hardware supply chain needs (including critical minerals) when scaling AI infrastructure to avoid bottlenecks.

items.title: Boosting AI Performance: Networking for AI Inference

ai.summary: Based on the available description (no transcript), Victor Moreno, Product Manager for Cloud Networking at Google, explains how Google Cloud's GKE Inference Gateway and AI-aware load balancing optimize AI inference by using inference-specific metrics, prefix caching, body-based routing, and service extensions. This approach aims to maximize GPU utilization, reduce latency and cold starts, and insert network-level AI guardrails to filter invalid or unsafe requests before they consume model compute.
bullets: AI-aware metrics (e.g., KV cache utilization, queue depth) replace traditional CPU-based signals to select least-loaded replicas.
Prefix caching and shadow copies let the gateway reuse prefill computations to lower GPU work and latency.
Body-based routing and LoRA adapter awareness enable routing by model/context rather than simple round-robin.
Service Extensions allow API management and AI guardrails to be inserted at the network edge to sanitize prompts/responses.
Results reported: improved GPU saturation, fewer cold starts, lower TCO, faster developer velocity, and reduced wasted compute from policy-violating requests.
takeaways: Power planning: Better GPU saturation can raise sustained power draw even as inefficiencies drop—expect shifts from spiky to more continuous power demand and plan provisioning and cooling accordingly.
Energy and cost savings: Network-level guardrails and cache reuse can reduce wasted GPU cycles (and associated energy), lowering operating costs for inference-heavy workloads.

Monitoring and metering: Data centers should add AI-specific telemetry (KV cache, queue depth, model-level routing metrics) to capacity and billing systems for accurate resource and energy accounting.
Network and latency requirements: Low-latency, high-throughput networking and support for service extensions at the edge become more important to realize inference efficiency gains.

Procurement and architecture: Maximizing GPU utilization via intelligent routing may change sizing choices (fewer, better-utilized GPU clusters versus many underutilized replicas) and influence procurement of GPUs, power infrastructure, and site resiliency.

items.title: Where Winds Meet is #RTXOn with DLSS 4 with Multi Frame Generation

ai.summary: Based on the available description, this is a short showcase for the open-world martial arts RPG Where Winds Meet highlighting NVIDIA's DLSS 4 with Multi Frame Generation and #RTXOn. No transcript is available; the clip is credited to DigitalDreamsyt and emphasizes visual/real-time rendering tech.
bullets: Open-world martial arts RPG: Where Winds Meet
Highlights DLSS 4 with Multi Frame Generation
Promotes #RTXOn (ray-tracing enabled visuals)
No transcript available in the provided content
Video credited to DigitalDreamsyt, published 2026-01-14
takeaways: DLSS 4 with Multi Frame Generation is presented as a rendering-efficiency feature — this could lower GPU compute per frame and affect energy per rendered frame, but no performance or power figures are included.

Wider adoption of advanced upscaling/frame-generation could drive demand for higher-end GPUs in cloud gaming and visualization services, with implications for data center power, cooling, and rack density planning.
Expect potential changes to utilization patterns (higher sustained or burst GPU loads); planners should seek concrete performance and power metrics from vendors before making capacity decisions.
Description lacks technical details — request vendor-spec power/throughput numbers to assess impacts on grid connections, UPS sizing, and renewables/storage integration.

items.title: The backbone of your steam plant’s reliability | GE Vernova

ai.summary: Based on the available description, this GE Vernova video focuses on assessing the remaining life of aging steam turbine rotors and options for what to do next to preserve plant reliability. It positions rotor end-of-life (EOL) planning and intervention as central to steam-plant uptime and performance.
bullets: Emphasizes anticipating remaining life of steam turbine rotors to avoid unexpected failures.
Frames rotor EOL assessment as a backbone activity for steam-plant reliability.
Implies available actions after assessment—repair, refurbishment, replacement, or life‑extension.
Points viewers to GE Vernova resources for more detail on rotor EOL services.
Positions this work within GE Vernova’s broader decarbonization and power‑generation mission.
takeaways: Plan rotor EOL assessments proactively to reduce risk of forced outages that impact grid reliability or data center backup power.
Use lifecycle/condition data to prioritize repairs or replacements and optimize capital spending versus risk exposure.
Coordinate OEM inspection and life‑extension options to maintain efficiency and meet decarbonization goals without unexpected downtime.
Integrate rotor EOL timelines into outage scheduling and spare‑parts strategies for critical facilities (substations, data centers).

items.title: Rynek dóbr luksusowych w obliczu transformacji | Andrzej Marczak, Tomasz Wiśniewski

ai.summary: Based on the available description, this KPMG ON AIR episode reviews how the luxury goods market is transforming — shifting toward experiences, personalization, ESG/responsible materials and “affordable luxury,” with Poland still growing even as global sales slow. Experts highlight market concentration (top 2% account for ~40%), Gen Z’s preference for experiences over possessions, rising luxury hospitality and art markets in Poland, and a future shaped by AI alongside traditional craftsmanship.
bullets: Trend toward experience-led luxury and deep personalization of customer journeys.
Market concentration: ~2% of the wealthiest clients drive about 40% of luxury sales.
ESG and ‘responsible luxury’ gaining importance (eco-leathers, certifications).
Poland: a growing but fragmented luxury market with rising aspirational consumers and expanding premium tourism.
Future directions include AI-enabled services combined with artisanal craftsmanship and human-led experiences.
takeaways: Rising luxury hospitality and premium tourism can create localized higher-power demand — planners should assess substation and distribution upgrades in premium destinations (e.g., Baltic coast, luxury hotels/spas).

AI-driven personalization and digital services for luxury brands imply increased compute needs and low-latency infrastructure — anticipate greater data-center/edge capacity and resilient power/cooling requirements.

ESG-driven brand requirements favor on-site renewables and storage for certifications and customer expectations — opportunities for integrated solar + battery projects at flagship stores, hotels, and galleries.

Long-term tech adoption in luxury (AI, high-end digital experiences) may increase demand for critical minerals via expanded compute and storage hardware procurement; procurement and lifecycle planning should factor in supply-chain and recycling strategies.

items.title: PJM: Reliable Electricity is Our Priority

ai.summary: Based on the available description, PJM Interconnection emphasizes that reliability has been its primary mission since 1927. The video outlines how PJM works to make sure electricity is available when needed.
bullets: Based on the description, the video highlights PJM's long-standing focus on reliability dating to 1927.
It aims to explain how PJM ensures electricity is 'there when you need it' (planning, operations, and coordination).
Emphasis on regional coordination between transmission owners, generators, and operators.
Likely touches on tools and processes used to manage supply/demand and respond to outages.
Relevance to critical users such as data centers and other large customers that depend on continuous power.
takeaways: For data centers: prioritize engagement with PJM processes (capacity, outages, interconnection) to align resilience plans with regional operations.
Design site-level resilience (backup generation, storage, demand response) knowing PJM focuses on system-wide reliability but local contingencies still matter.
Monitor PJM planning and market signals to anticipate changes in capacity, transmission projects, and resource mix that affect availability and cost.
Participate in regional programs (capacity, demand response, interconnection queues) to help secure supply and potentially offset operating costs.

ai.summary: Based on the available description, Hitachi Energy presents digital-first power grid technologies as essential for balancing reliability, flexibility and efficiency while expanding capacity to support the energy transition. Their offerings are framed to improve system stability, reduce downtime and optimize performance across power network layers.
bullets: Focus on digital technologies at the core of grid modernization.
Aims to balance reliability, flexibility and efficiency while expanding capacity.
Targets improved stability and reduced downtime across networks.
Optimizes performance at multiple levels (transmission, distribution, substations).
Positioned for supporting renewable and storage integration during the energy transition.
takeaways: Prioritize digital grid solutions that enhance visibility and control to improve stability and uptime.
Evaluate vendor offerings for their ability to reduce downtime and optimize operational performance.
Design capacity expansions with flexibility to accommodate renewables and storage integration.
Data center power planners should coordinate with grid modernization efforts to secure reliable, optimized supply.

ai.summary: Based on the available description, Hitachi Energy frames industrial resilience around energy efficiency, process optimization and digital integration. The company says it partners with customers to build smarter systems that boost productivity, reliability and sustainability across operations.
bullets: Resilience rests on energy efficiency, optimized processes and digital integration.
Hitachi Energy emphasizes collaboration with customers and partners.
Goal is smarter systems that raise productivity across operations.
Improved reliability is presented as a core outcome of digitalized systems.
Sustainability is a key objective alongside productivity and reliability.
takeaways: Prioritize energy-efficiency investments and process optimization to strengthen operational resilience in grids and data centers.
Digital integration (analytics, controls, automation) is a practical lever to improve reliability and productivity for substations and critical facilities.
Partnering with technology and service providers can accelerate deployment of smarter systems and help meet sustainability targets.
Track metrics for productivity, reliability and sustainability to guide technology choices and justify investments.
